title: Lesson 2: Tenses
description: Learn about different tenses in English!

sections.heading: Simple Present
sections.text: The simple present tense is used to describe habits, unchanging situations, general truths, and fixed arrangements.
examples: The sun rises in the east.

sections.heading: Simple Past
sections.text: The simple past tense is used to talk about completed actions in the past.

sections.heading: Simple Future
sections.text: The simple future tense is used to talk about things that haven't happened yet.
examples: I will travel to Japan next month.
She will start her new job soon.

sections.heading: Present Continuous
sections.text: The present continuous tense is used to describe actions that are happening at the current moment.
examples: He is studying for his exam.

sections.heading: Past Continuous
sections.text: The past continuous tense is used to describe actions that were ongoing at a specific time in the past.
examples: She was reading a book when I called.
They were watching TV all night.

sections.heading: Future Continuous
sections.text: The future continuous tense indicates an action that will be ongoing at a specific time in the future.
examples: At this time tomorrow, I will be flying to New York.
She will be working on her project all day.

sections.heading: Present Perfect
sections.text: The present perfect tense is used to describe actions that happened at an unspecified time before now, or that began in the past and continue to the present.
examples: He has lived here for five years.

sections.heading: Past Perfect
sections.text: The past perfect tense is used to describe an action that was completed before another action in the past.
examples: She had finished her work before he arrived.
By the time I got there, they had already left.

sections.heading: Future Perfect
sections.text: The future perfect tense indicates an action that will be completed before another action in the future.
examples: By next year, I will have graduated from university.
She will have finished the report by the time the meeting starts.
